Discharge Instructions:
Medications
You will be given a prescription for pain medicine.

NOTE 2 The pain 
medication is a codeine derivative and should be taken as

NOTE 2 Please take one full strength aspirin (325 mg) each day for six 
weeks to decrease the risk of having a complication related to a 
blood clot.

NOTE 2 Please take a stool softener, like Colace (Docusate Sodium 
100mg), twice a day while taking narcotics to prevent 
constipation.

NOTE 2 Dressing
Leave your dressing for 48 hours after your surgery.

NOTE 2 After 48 
hours, you may remove your dressing.

NOTE 2 LEAVE THE TAPE STRIPS OVER 
YOUR INCISIONS.

NOTE 2 These will stay on for 1.5 to 2 weeks and will 
slowly peel off.

NOTE 2 Showering
You may shower 48 hours after your surgery and get your 
incisions wet.

NOTE 2 DO NOT immerse in a tub or pool for 7  10 days 
to avoid excessive scarring and risk of infection.

NOTE 2 When you shower, let your arm hang at your side (Do NOT raise 
your arm).

NOTE 2 To wash under your arm, lean forward carefully and let your arm 
hang.
NOTE 2 Using your other hand, wash under your operative arm.

NOTE 2 Do 
NOT scrub the incision.

NOTE 2 When you are done, stand up and let 
your arm hang at your side.

NOTE 2 Pat yourself dry and put your sling 
on.

NOTE 2 Ice Packs
Keep Ice Packs on at all times exchanging every hour while 
awake.

NOTE 2 Icing is very important to decrease swelling and pain 
and improve mobility.

NOTE 2 After 24 hours, continue to use the cuff 
3  4 times a day, 15  20 minutes each time to keep swelling to 
a minimum.

NOTE 2 Activity
 Take it easy.
NOTE 2  Wear your sling for comfort and safety.

NOTE 2  Keep your arm at your side at ALL TIMES  no reaching, 
grabbing or pulling with your operative arm.

Brief Hospital Course:
Global Assessment:
Mr. ___ is a ___ single, unemployed (on SSDI), HIV positive man 
with history of depression, alcohol use disorder, numerous 
psychiatric hospitalizations, and ___ prior suicide attempts 
including OD on Tylenol in ___ who presented to ___ ED 
acutely intoxicated and on sober evaluation expressed worsening 
depression and suicidal ideation in the context of ongoing 
alcohol use, absence of psychiatric treatment, and severe social 
stressors.

NOTE 10 Initial examination revealed an unkempt, dypshoric 
man with low mood and neurovegetative symptom consistent with 
depression.

NOTE 10 His hopelessness, fatigue, and amotivation over the last several 
months have led to noncompliance with HIV medications and 
escalating alcohol use, both of which have contributed to a 
significant deterioration in his physical and emotional health.

NOTE 10 Mr. ___ decompensation is intimately related to severe social 
stressors, including financial hardship, risk of eviction, and 
caring for a sick and abusive mother, and the absence of any 
psychosocial support figures.

NOTE 10 Diagnostically, patient most 
likely has a substance induced mood disorder superimposed on a 
primary mood disorder, although a mood disorder secondary to 
another medical condition (HIV) is also a possibility.

NOTE 10 # Legal:
___
# Safety:
 - Mr. ___ was calm and controlled on the unit.

NOTE 10 There were no 
safety/behavioral issues.

NOTE 10 He was kept on standard Q15 minute 
checks and unit restriction.

NOTE 10 # Psychiatric:
Diagnoses/Differential:
 - Alcohol use disorder
 - Substance induced mood disorder
 - History of major depressive disorder
 - R/o mood disorder secondary to other medical condition

Extensive time was spent discussing the Mr. ___ diagnosis and 
psychopharmacology issues.

NOTE 10 He participated in treatment 
planning.

NOTE 10 Mr. ___ was not on any psychiatric medications at time of 
admission.
NOTE 10 He was started on citalopram to treat his depression.

NOTE 10 B/R/AE/SE including but not limited to sedation, GI upset, 
overactivation were discussed.

NOTE 10 This medication was 
well-tolerated, and likely contributed to the improvement in 
patient's dypshoria and neurovegetative symptoms.

NOTE 10 Early interviews were notable for extended pauses before 
answering questions, which raised concern for HIV associated 
dementia.

NOTE 10 A MOCA examination was completed, and he scored ___, 
with deficits in visuospatial/executive function, attention, 
language, and delayed recall.

NOTE 10 Mr. ___ was subsequently referred 
for neuropsychological testing.

NOTE 10 On RBANS Neuropsychiatric test, 
Mr. ___ demonstrated subtle deficits in new learning (immediate 
memory) and delayed memory, which could signify early, prodromal 
signs of dementia in a patient who is generally of average to 
high intelligence.

NOTE 10 The majority of his scores were within one 
standard deviation of the mean for his age.

NOTE 10 List recognition was 
the only task greater than two SDs below the mean.

NOTE 10 Mr. ___ did 
very well with digit span, a task patients with significant 
cognitive deficits typically struggle with.

NOTE 10 Overall, the results 
were not consistent with a clear neurocognitive disorder, but he 
should be monitored for ongoing cognitive collapse.

NOTE 10 Clinically, 
his cognitive status improved over the course of the 
hospitalization, suggesting that alcohol and depression may have 
been significant factors.

NOTE 10 Mr. ___ initially stated that he had no outpatient providers but 
later informed team that he had seen a social worker through ___ 
at the ___.

NOTE 10 This therapist, ___ 
(___) was contacted on ___.

NOTE 10 Her discussions with 
Mr. ___ generally focused on his relationship with his mother 
and their evolving codependence.

NOTE 10 He was unwilling to discuss his 
substance abuse with her and denied he had any problem.

NOTE 10 In the 
past few months he had stopped seeing her or taking his 
medications and believed he was far from his baseline based on 
the description of his initial evaluation, believing him to be 
acutely decompensated secondary to depression and substance use.

NOTE 10 Throughout his hospitalization, he began to become more forward 
thinking and future oriented.

NOTE 10 For example, he began working on 
necessary arrangements to care for his finances, which he had 
neglected for several months.

NOTE 10 Furthermore, he made arrangements 
to assure he would receive his proper HIV medications upon his 
transfer to ___, showing he had overcome the passive 
suicidality of medication noncompliance that was of initial 
concern upon admission.

NOTE 10 # Substance Use: Alcohol
Patient arrived at the emergency room intoxicated.

NOTE 10 He was 
monitored on CIWA during the first few days of hospitalization 
and completed detoxification without incident.

NOTE 10 Patient was educated on the way in which drugs and alcohol 
affect behavior, mood, interpersonal relationships, and physical 
health.

NOTE 10 Patient was encouraged to abstain from all alcohol and 
illicit drug use and participate in AA/NA on a daily basis upon 
discharge from inpatient facilities.

NOTE 10 In terms of treatment readiness, patient was in precontemplation 
stage.

NOTE 10 He described alcohol as his "obsession" and avoided 
talking about the consequences of his drinking or initiating 
treatment that would support his sobreity.

NOTE 10 Throughout his 
hospitalization he became more acknowledging of his alcohol use 
and agreed that further treatment at ___ specifically for his 
alcohol use would be beneficial.

NOTE 10 # Medical:
Patients PCP ___ was contacted during the 
admission in order to discuss circumstances of patients 
hospitalization, obtain relevant history, and arrange 
appropriate follow up.

NOTE 10 The following medical problems were addressed during this 
hospitalization:
 - Transaminitis: likely elevated in setting of alcohol use and

NOTE 10 LFTs were initially uptrending to >300 but then began to

NOTE 10 Synthetic function (INR) remained within

NOTE 10 Liver service was consulted and given the

withdrawal, however, given its persistence, lisinopril 5mg daily

NOTE 10 - Macrocytosis: likely secondary to ETOH.

NOTE 10 B12 within normal 
limits.

NOTE 15 RISK ASSESSMENT
On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon 
static risk factors including Caucasian race, single status, 
chronic medical illnesses, and modifiable risk factors including 
difficult relationship with outpatient providers, irritability 
and impulsivity, and inability to deny SI at the time of 
admission.

NOTE 15 The modifiable risk factors were addressed during 
this hospitalization through the provision of individual, group 
and milieu therapy aimed at improving coping skills, a family 
meeting held with her outpatient providers and brother with the 
goal of improving her relationship with them and improving her 
willingness to engage in treatment, and medication adjustments 
targeting her impulsivity and irritability.

NOTE 15 Finally, the 
patient is being discharged with many protective risk factors 
including help-seeking nature, future oriented viewpoint, 
patient not endorsing SI or HI, no current substance abuse, and 
agreement to work with her outpatient treaters in a more 
thoughtful manner and to engage in once a week DBT therapy.

NOTE 15 Overall based on the totality of our assessment at this time, 
the patient is not at an acutely elevated risk of self-harm nor 
danger to others.

Brief Hospital Course:
#) Psychiatric
At admission Ms ___ was found to be exceedingly dysphoric 
with overwhelming tearfulness and sense of hopelessness, and 
ambivalence around her hospitalization.

NOTE 16 On the unit she again 
endorsed the numerous depressive symptoms such as insomnia, 
decreased energy, guilt, and prior suicidality though seemed 
prone to minimizing the severity of the episode, especially 
early on.

NOTE 16 She also agreed that recent escalating alcohol use 
likely contributed to her acute change and need for 
presentation.

NOTE 16 For her apparent major depressive episode she was 
started on bupropion SR 100mg BID, which she tolerated and was 
increased to 150mg BID and continued through discharge.

NOTE 16 Trazodone at 25mg was also used for insomnia on a PRN basis with 
good effect.

NOTE 16 She experienced fair improvement in her mental 
status with decreased mood reactivity and tearfulness and better 
interpersonal engagement with the team later in her course.

NOTE 16 Over 
her short hospitalization she was consistently visible on the 
unit milieu and in groups with positive interactions with other 
patients.

NOTE 16 She consistently denied any further lingering suicidal 
ideations after her initial eval in the ED.

NOTE 16 Her insight into the 
severity of the episode and need for multi-faceted treatment 
also improved closer to discharge.

NOTE 16 #) Alcohol
History suggests and the patient agrees that alcohol misuse 
likely played a role in the decompensation and presentation 
leading to this admission.

NOTE 16 She agreed that eliminating this as a 
contributing agent would be a good idea.

NOTE 16 Does likely meet 
criteria for abuse though not full dependence.

NOTE 16 #) Medical
Her home diuretic and hormone replacement were continued and no 
particular intervention was required.

NOTE 16 She noticed a mild 
headache and question of asymmetry of the facial musculature at 
one point though neuro exam was negative and the HA resolved 
with ibuprofen.

NOTE 16 #) Legal
Ms ___ signed in voluntarily and remained as such for the 
duration of her course.

NOTE 16 #) Social/Dispo:

treatment and discharge planning.

NOTE 16 Husband ___ came to visit 
over weekend and again for collective meeting with the team day 
prior to d/c.

NOTE 16 She will return home and pick up care with new 
outpatient providers including, briefly, the ___ 
___ immediately after discharge.

NOTE 16 #) Risk assessment:
Ms ___ carries a small number of chronic risk factors for 
poor outcome like self-harm or suicide, namely her limited 
insight and willingness to participate in mental health 
treatment.

NOTE 16 Acute risk factors which have been addressed include 
major depressive episode, alcohol misuse behaviors, and lack of 
outpatient treatment outreach.

NOTE 16 She remains protected by her 
education and work motivation with good future orientation, sex, 
lack of major substance dependence, lack of access to weapons, 
and dependent children.

NOTE 16 This profile suggests the outpatient 
setting will be the least restrictive sufficient environment.

NOTE 18 Mental status examination on admission was concerning for mania 
with psychotic features-- patient appears well groomed but is 
notably hyperthymic and expansive with rapid speech, thought 
process that is notable for derailments, tangentiality, 
looseness of associations and thought content that is concerning 
for ideas of reference and paranoid delusions (that likely have 
some basis in reality).
NOTE 18 .

NOTE 18 Diagnostically, given his young age and presentation, I am 
concerned for an affective psychosis at this time, particularly 
BPAD Type I, manic, with psychotic features.

NOTE 18 However, his 
cannabis use may very well be contributing to his current 
presentation, and I cannot rule out substance induced 
psychosis/mania at this time.

NOTE 18 Given his young age and good 
health, an underlying medical condition is unlikely to be 
contributing to his current presentation.

NOTE 18 Given lack of negative 
symptoms, apparent lack of prodromal phase, I think that a 
primary psychotic disorder such as schizophrenia is further down 
on the differential.

NOTE 18 Of note, although the patient has a history 
of trauma and PTSD symptoms, he does not appear anxious, 
dysphoric, or distressed on my examination-- I do not believe is
presentation is due to untreated PTSD or anxiety symptoms, 
although certainly he is at high risk for anxiety disorders.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old male with a history of T10 
paraplegia, neurogenic bladder & recurrent UTIs, recent 
pre-admission question of paranoia/psychosis, who presented with 
syncope multiple times daily.

NOTE 24 Patient reported losing 
consciousness up to 5x/day daily for months.

NOTE 24 All work-up was 
unremarkable.
NOTE 24 EEG showed mild encephalopathy but no seizures.

NOTE 24 CT 
head and C spine showed mild cervical spondylosis.

NOTE 24 Orthostatics 
negative.
NOTE 24 Telemetry without events.

NOTE 24 Patient reported that he had 
no episodes of syncope in the hospital and none were witnessed.

NOTE 24 Psychiatry evaluated the patient and diagnosed schizophrenia 
with psychosis exacerbated by drug and medication use (cocaine 
and Concerta) and started the patient on Risperdal.

NOTE 24 Syncope was 
felt to be psychiatric in nature, however history also notable 
for significant caffeine intake in addition to ADHD medication 
and severe insomnia.

NOTE 24 ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
============================

#SYNCOPE: 
Unclear etiology.

NOTE 24 Never witnessed by the patient's family and 
has not had any events during this hospitalization.

NOTE 24 No history 
of seizures.

NOTE 24 Question of whether this was a case of psychiatric 
syncope which typically presents in younger patients with 
psychiatric disorders, without cardiovascular or neurologic 
disease.

NOTE 24 Another consideration was drug/med effect from opiates, 
other illegal drugs given that the patient's urine tox was 
positive for opiates (on MS ___ and cocaine.

NOTE 24 The patient 
emphasized how little he sleeps (stays up late playing video 
games, watching TV, often only gets ___ hours of sleep a night), 
and somnolence secondary to this was felt to be a contributing 
factor as well given that the patient had no episodes in the 
hospital and was well rested here.

NOTE 24 Also endorsed drinking 
multiple caffeinated drinks daily in addition to ADHD 
medication.

NOTE 24 Not felt to be cardiac or neurogenic as ECG, 
telemetry and EEG showed nothing except for mild encephalopathy.

NOTE 24 Ultimately felt when discharged that this would continue to 
resolve with improved psychiatric care as outlined below.

NOTE 24 #PSYCHOSIS with suspected schizophrenia: 
Based upon rambling and disorganized speech in addition to 
delusions of the government following him confirmed by his 
family.

NOTE 24 He also previously endorsed paranoia and visual 
hallucinations.

NOTE 24 Per psych likely chronic and then triggered by 
cocaine (and possibly other drug) use and Concerta.

NOTE 24 UTI felt to 
have contributed to the patient's decompensation as well.

NOTE 24 Thyroid function appeared normal (TSH was low but barely below 
low normal limits and free T4 was well within normal limits) so 
hyperthyroidism was felt much less likely.

NOTE 24 Additionally he had 
no other physiologic symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

NOTE 24 The patient's 
morphine was tapered since he violated his narcotics contract 
and his home Concerta was held indefinitely.

NOTE 24 His UTI was treated 
as noted below and he was started on risperidone  QHS per psych.

NOTE 29 Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of weakness and difficulty 
speaking resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition 
where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain 
is blocked by a clot.

NOTE 29 The brain is the part of your body that 
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage 
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result 
in a variety of symptoms.

NOTE 29 Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke.

NOTE 29 In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors.

NOTE 29 Your risk factors are:

Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
History of a prior stroke

We are changing your medications as follows:
You are continuing on aspirin
You are continuing on plavix
You are continuing atorvastatin 80

Please take your other medications as prescribed.

NOTE 29 Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.

NOTE 29 Additionally, you were evaluated by our speech and swallow 
service as you were unable to safely swallow.

NOTE 29 You had a feeding 
tube placed, which allowed us to feed you while it was unsafe 
for you to swallow.

NOTE 29 By the end of the hospitalization, you were 
able to safely swallow!

NOTE 29 We will have to set up for you to have 
the feeding tube removed when it is safe to do so.

NOTE 29 If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911).

NOTE 29 In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

NOTE 31 ___ have a new ileostomy.

NOTE 31 The most common complication from a 
new ileostomy placement is dehydration.

NOTE 31 The output from the 
stoma is stool from the small intestine and the water content is 
very high.

NOTE 31 The stool is no longer passing through the large 
intestine which is where the water from the stool is reabsorbed 
into the body and the stool becomes formed.

NOTE 31 ___ must measure 
your ileostomy output for the next few weeks.

NOTE 31 The output from 
the stoma should not be more than 1500cc or less than 500cc.

NOTE 31 If 
___ find that your output has become too much or too little, 
please call the office for advice.

NOTE 31 The office nurse or nurse 
practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the 
ileostomy output.

NOTE 31 Keep yourself well hydrated, if ___ notice 
your ileostomy output increasing, take in more electrolyte drink 
such as Gatorade.

NOTE 31 Please monitor yourself for signs and symptoms 
of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon standing), 
weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue.

NOTE 31 If ___ notice these 
symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room

regular diet with your new ileostomy.

NOTE 31 However it is a good idea 
to avoid fatty or spicy foods and follow diet suggestions made

for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses.

(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be

the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact.

skin around the stoma for bulging or signs of infection listed

hospitalization included: disorganized and unpredictable 
behavior, active cannabis use, and limited coping skills.

NOTE 36 Patient attended groups regularly to learn coping skills and 
meditation skills.

use and patient agrees to cut back use.

unpredictable behavior, patient maintains that this was not an

including speaking with his wife, ___ worker, and psychiatric

harm risk include: children in the home, strong sense of 
responsibility to family, married relationship status, 
help-seeking behavior, life satisfaction, future-oriented 
viewpoint, strong social supports including ___ 
worker, ___, and wraparound supports, consistent outpatient 
___, positive therapeutic relationship with outpatient 
providers, medication compliance, no access to lethal weapons, 
intact reality-testing ability, and cooperation with treatment 
team recommendations.

self-harm given the above risk factors, he has strong social 
supports, and several close family members and outpatient 
providers who feel he has been doing well for the past couple of 
years, are comfortable with his discharge, and are not actively 
concerned for his safety.

hydroxycut toxicity, no acute stressor (chronic financial 
stressors), confounded toxicology screen, and continuous denial 
of suicide attempt, am inclined to rule ingestion as

preserved capacity to engage in a meaningful conversation about

providers, tell family members, call ___, or go to the emergency 
room).

ongoing inpatient admission due to decompensated psychiatric

21, improved to 10 with IVF.

4.4, which improved to 3 with fluids.

thiamine deficiency, methyl salicylate, and alcoholic 
ketoacidosis which may have contributed.

considered unlikely given normal renal function (ethylene 
glycol) and absence of visual findings (methanol).

(accounting for EtOH) on admission.

NOTE 42 after hydration, osmolar gap 
normalized to 4.

NOTE 42 Toxicology was consulted, and recommended no 
further intervention.

NOTE 42 See above discussion of ethylene glycol 
and methanol.

NOTE 42 Additional consideration was isopropyl alcohol, 
which felt to be unlikely.
NOTE 42 .

seizures.

NOTE 42 He was 
scoring highly, requiring valium.

NOTE 42 He was encouraged to seek 
inpatient detoxification, but he declined.

patient should be kept in house to monitor for signs of 
withdrawal, but the patient requested to leave Against Medical 
Advice the morning of admission.

for thiamine and a multivitamin in addition to folic acid and

Brief Hospital Course:
PSYCHIATRIC

Ms. ___ was admitted after leaving a suicide note for her 
mother while very heavily using alcohol and cocaine in the 
context of multiple psychosocial stressors including losing her 
job on that day and a recent night in jail for a driving 
violation.

NOTE 44 On admission she regretted her actions and expressed 
feeling very embarassed by what had happened.

NOTE 44 She said that 
alcohol had become a problem for her in the last ___ years and 
cocaine had been problematic for several months.

NOTE 44 She had been 
hiding her heavy substance abuse from her family and treaters.

NOTE 44 We provided her psychoeducation on the effects of alcohol on 
one's mental and physical health and helped her explore what 
sobriety could mean to her.

NOTE 44 Ms. ___ family was heavily 
involved, and please see family collateral section below for 
further details.

NOTE 44 During this hospitalization, we provided daily individual, 
milieu, and group therapy.

NOTE 44 We monitored her on a CIWA for 
alcohol withdrawal, and she required diazepam for elevated CIWA 
scores on only a few occasions.

NOTE 44 On admission, her LFTs were 
elevated with an AST 128 and ALT 120, which we monitored during 
her hospitalization and decreased to AST 58 and ALT 109, most 
likely reflecting alcohol cessation.

NOTE 44 We discussed medication 
options such as naltrexone or acamprosate to help control 
cravings, but Ms. ___ did not feel that cravings were her 
main issue and declined these aforementioned options.

NOTE 44 We started 
her on daily multivitamins, thiamine, and folate which she 
should continue for at least a month if she continues to be 
sober.

NOTE 44 We discussed multiple aftercare options with Ms. ___ 
and ___ family, and stressed that substance abuse treatment 
would be imperative for her.

NOTE 44 She decided on starting a partial 
hospitalization program which focused on dual diagnosis patients 
immediately following discharge.

NOTE 44 In addition to the heavy substance abuse, Ms. ___ endorsed 
feeling depressed, and had recollections of feeling depressed 
prior to the substance abuse.

NOTE 44 She also described significant 
anxiety with several panic symptoms such as palpitations.

NOTE 44 We 
continued her fluoxetine and started her on hydroxyzine for 
anxiety, which we explained was a better choice given her 
polysubstance abuse than clonazepam which she had been on in the 
past.

NOTE 44 While she had felt suicidal at the time that she had left 
the note, she denied any suicidal ideation while hospitalized.

NOTE 44 In contrast, she was quite future oriented and very involved in 
aftercare planning with the treatment team.

NOTE 44 She described 
wanting to get sober to be able to spend time with her nephews, 
find a new job, and establish healthy relationships with her 
family and new friends.

NOTE 44 On discharge, mood was "anxious", MSE was pertinent for a 
Caucasian woman who appears her stated age, wearing casual 
clothes, with good hygiene and grooming.

NOTE 44 She is cooperative, 
engaged, and maintains good eye contact throughout the 
interview.

NOTE 44 There is no evidence of psychomotor retardation or 
agitation.

NOTE 44 She describes her mood as "anxious" and her affect is 
mood-congruent as she appears mostly euthymic with some anxiety 
and moments of brightness.

NOTE 44 Her thought process is linear, 
logical, and goal directed.

NOTE 44 Her thought content is devoid of any 
delusional thoughts, hallucinations, or suicidal or homicidal 
ideation.

NOTE 44 Her speech is regular rate, and with normal volume and 
prosody.

NOTE 44 Her judgment and insight have improved since the time 
of admission.

NOTE 44 Safety: The patient remained in good behavioral control 
throughout this hospitalization and did not require physical or 
chemical restraint.

NOTE 44 The patient remained on 15 minute checks, 
which is our lowest acuity level of checks.

NOTE 44 RISK ASSESSMENT:
This patient s not suicidal or homicidal, is feeling well and is 
animated, euthymic, and participatory in the milieu, all of 
which indicate a low immediate risk of harm.

NOTE 44 Static risk factors include:
- History of abuse as a child
- Chronic medical illness

Modifiable risk factors include:
- Active polysubstance abuse
- Limited outpatient support in substance abuse field
- Recent job loss
- Active suicidal ideation on presentation 

We modified this risk by helping the patient find appropriate 
outpatient substance abuse treatment, addressing the 
polysubstance abuse with the patient and helped her discuss it 
with her family, and provided education and support surrounding 
sobriety.

NOTE 44 Protective factors include:
- Strong connection to family 
- Skills in problem solving, conflict resolution, and handling 
problems in a non-violent way
- No history of suicide attempts
- No history of psychiatric hospitalizations

Current risk is low for intentional self-harm given that the 
patient denies suicidal ideation, intent and plan, is accepting 
of treatment, is currently sober and is future oriented with 
plans to return home with her mother and engage in a partial 
hospitalization program starting tomorrow.

and benefits of possible alternatives, including not taking the 
medication, with this patient.

NOTE 44 We discussed the patient's right 
to decide whether to take this medication as well as the 
importance of the patient's actively participating in the 
treatment and discussing any questions about medications with 
the treatment team, and I answered the patient's questions.

NOTE 44 The 
patient appeared able to understand and consented to begin the 
medication.

This is a ___ year old man with no formal medical or psychiatric

ago after he found out his girlfriend and mother of his ___ month 
old child was cheating on him.

NOTE 45 In this setting, patient reported 
he became acutely distraught with 2 days of insomnia, low mood, 
poor appetite, attempting to hang himself with a belt in his 
house which he shares with his girlfriend and her family.

NOTE 45 On my 
interview, patient currently denies depressed mood, anxiety, NVS 
on examination and states that his suicide attempt was a means 
to obtain his girlfriend's attention.

NOTE 45 MSE notable for a well 
groomed, cooperative man with good eye contact, denial of all
depressive symptoms and thought process that is notably linear, 
logical, goal and future oriented.
NOTE 45 .

with adjustment disorder with depressed mood with improvement of 
depression in the setting of reported resolution of conflict 
with his girlfriend.

current depressive episode-- he is not dysthymic or dysphoric on
examination, although I am concerned he may be minimizing his 
current symptoms, and appears euthymic.

NOTE 45 Denies symptoms of 
anxiety and denies SI or thoughts of self harm.

NOTE 45 Nothing in his 
history to suggest a history of manic symptoms and he is 
certainly not manic on my examination.

NOTE 45 Denies history of 
psychotic symptoms and nothing on examination that is concerning 
for acute psychosis.

NOTE 45 Given young age and good health, underlying 
medical condition is unlikely to be playing a role in his 
presentation.

negative tox screen, I do not believe that alcohol or substance 
use is a factor in his presentation.
